title: Ghoom Monastery
review_text:
At a grand elevation of 8,000 feet, the Yiga Choeling or old Ghoom Monastery is the oldest Tibetan Buddhist Monastery of Darjeeling. Established in 1850 by Lama Sherab Gyatso, this shrine is part of the Yellow Hat sect known as Gelupka who worship the 'Coming Buddha' or 'Maitreyi Buddha'. A 15-foot high statue of Maitreyi Buddha is seen in the central hall, made entirely of clay brought from Tibet. This statue was installed during the tenure of the second head of the monastery Lama Domo Geshe Rinpoche. One can also find many rare Buddhist manuscripts within the premises. Visitors are treated to a beautiful view of the majestic Kanchenjunga outside the monastery. Prayer flags are flown by the resident monks in typical Tibetan tradition. Within Yiga Choeling, one can view images of many Buddha deities and lamas such as the Chenrezig, Buddha of compassion, and Tsongkhapa, the founder of the Gelupka sect. In front of the Maitreya Buddha statue hang two huge oil lamps which keep burning throughout the year. title: Calm, Compact, Easily Accessible
review_text:
Ghum Monastery is readily accessible within the city, making it different from most other Monasteries which are at isolated hill side locations. It is a single compact hall within a larger gated compound. 
A central tall, seated colourful statue of Buddha rising to the high roof dominates the hall. The walls are covered with Buddhist paintings & several colourful large Buddhist hangings stand out in the hall. Lines of cushioned seats are present on the floor, possibly for monks during studies or prayers. Several other statues of Buddhist icons are seen. The rush of visitors tends to overfill the compact hall. Visitor chatter diminishes the calm silence of the premises. 
Ghum Monastery is more a visual colorful place of Buddhist worship. More
